column2: A high quality evidence-based podcast packed with insightful discussions with a broad range of diverse professionals. All perspectives are considered. eg. leaders, rising stars, quiet achievers, colleagues, folks underrepresented in leadership and more. Both practical and aspirational advice shared for professionals at different career stages and levels of expertise. Thanks to everyone in the Women at Work team!  üëèüèΩüëèüèº #womeninSTEMM #science #technology #engineering #mathematics #medicine

A refreshing, insightful and no holds barred encapsulation of modernity. It‚Äôs a cracking start to my morning hearing these inspiring, feisty intelligent women banter, interview, probe and dissect modern work life. Amen HBR what a program! Throughly worth investing your valuable ear-time.

column2: There‚Äôs so much high level advice out there without the micro skills and phrasing to go with it. Thank you for creating something so useful. I shall be listening to it several times and noting some of the useful phrases. Very valuable, thank you thank you!
I really enjoyed these and am hoping more are being produced.

This is one of the top podcasts available right now. The hosts and guests are right on their game, well researched, balanced, authentic and genuinely interesting. Aimed at women in the workplace but would also be good for men who want insight into the issues we discuss when they are not around.

I LOVE this podcast. I really appreciate that there is such a thoughtful, insightful podcast that focuses on women in the workplace. What I particularly love is that the podcast is run by women and brings in a relational, and personally reflective approach to interactions amongst the hosts and with guests - whilst at the same time providing thought-provoking and useful information for any woman (and probably any man too) - as I‚Äôm sure that some of the issues that men and women face in the workplace overlap and are not entirely dissimilar. Thanks for this podcast! It‚Äôs refreshing and engaging every time.

This is an excellent new podcast series. Great guests bring useful advice and insights to the discussion, but I particularly enjoy and appreciate the thoughtful, honest and personal reflection from the co-hosts. Highly recommended!
Great ideas. Great suggestions. This is very helpful for women navigating work issues in a thoughtful and research based way. Worth the listen!

I find this is my go-to podcast. You cover so many topics that are relevant for me as a working mom of teens, trying navigating advancing in my career, finding fulfillment, juggling work with being a school trustee all while seeking balance. Thank you for your encouragement, thoughts and advice.

As an Asian female leader working in a white male dominant industry, this is my go to podcast when I felt stuck, pushed over and overwhelmed at work.  From the bottom of my heart, thank you for being there for us.
column4: Mom of 3 kids + one new born

column2: I appreciate the depth and insights of this show, that it is not a black and white,  us versus them kind of perspective on work place equality. I learnt a lot. But also, I want to see more diverse perspectives represented in the discussion of workplace politics.

I listen to this podcast as motivation, when I‚Äôm feeling dismissed at work, overwhelmed with motherhood, or when I just need a reminder that we‚Äôre all in it together as an invisible sisterhood. 
Is my favourite podcast. Thank you, ladies!!
Really love the variety of topics plus the quality of the guests. Some great research and commentary. So glad I found this!
This podcast is amazing for females seeking future talent in professional settings. Women are an absolute asset in both workforce and corporate world. Diversity increases chances of business success.

this postcast is a must listen to any woman in a corporate field, they give examples and specific ways how to improve yourself and not wait for opportunities to make them. I really have enjoyed all their episodes! I need more !!

I believe that the discussion on the this podcast is must for every women, especially those that are entering the job market or getting their career started. I also believe that men have a lot to learn about the reality of women in the workforce and their challenges and this would be a good place for them to learn about these issues and how to approach them with their colleagues, both female and male. I find that this podcast is a very thoughtful one examining these issues, issues that affect everyone in way or another, and, some that are not only gender specific.
Listening more could be useful for all.

Poignant, thought provoking and extremely insightful. column2: I absolutely love this podcast. From the inspiring interviews to the practical tips shared, every episode is a must-listen. I found the entire series very useful, but I wanted to highlight the episode re supporting employees with children with mental health challenges. I‚Äôve gone through this in the past three years with various leadership teams and who is on top makes a world of a difference in my own performance at work and trying to manage making sure I‚Äôm bringing my a game to work and to ensuring my children have what they need to thrive.

I love this new series with Amy Gallo: Getting Along.  The practical tips and reframing are so much more powerful in this ‚Äúcall-in consultation‚Äù format.  I especially loved the Tormentor episode, as I had a similar work situation to the caller, and found the insights and techniques powerful, insightful, validating (and challenging).

Love this who‚Äôs and was excited to hear it. Just came out today and it‚Äôs not working :/

I am a cis gender male, who manages a gender diverse team, and this podcast is among my favorites - not just as a manager but as a human in the workforce.

The depth of every episode is in line with the best podcasts ever produced, and well beyond the scope of a standard business podcast. 

One of my favorite aspects is the thoughtful processing after each interview, where the hosts digest the interview and highlight personal takeaways.

This podcast is well worth your time.

They conveniently disregard the fact men are more likely to be unemployed, lack a college education, be homeless, die younger, lack health insurance, lose custody of their kids, suffer from addiction, etc.

Deloitte Digital sponsors this exceptional podcast and too often we forget to thank them so want them to know that their message is getting through and associating their company with such a quality series ( ashamed to say I only discovered it recently but have gone back to listen to the previous seasons) will help them gain new clients and engender good faith from their existing clients. Thank you Amy B Amy G and Nicole for bringing your A game always. The guests are great but I really enjoy when the three of you discuss the topic after the guest.

I found this podcast when I was looking around for career-oriented shows. I‚Äôd subscribed to a few other related podcasts before, but they‚Äôre all hit and miss. It‚Äôs not to say they‚Äôre terrible or useless or anything so drastic, but I can honestly say that sometimes, I skip an episode. 

That‚Äôs not the case with Women at Work. I enjoy this show so much! The topics are engaging and thoughtful, and the hosts do a wonderful job of really digging in to the nuances of what it‚Äôs actually like to be a woman in the workplace. 

Thank you for your research and efforts. I am truly a fan, and I would recommend Women at Work to any woman, whether she‚Äôs working in an office, at home, or is a stay-at-home mom. It‚Äôs nice to feel like someone else has your back, and sometimes, a mentoring career woman with more experience than you is really helpful. I‚Äôd also recommend this podcast to men, because let‚Äôs be real: men could use a LOT more insight into the issues women have to deal with in the workplace. A little empathy wouldn‚Äôt hurt either! 

Long story short, Women at Work is exactly what I hoped it would be, and I am very glad to have found the show. Thanks again.
column5: This is exactly what I hoped it would be

I just joined a more corporate work environment after being a teacher for several years, when my life plan was radically different, and this Podcast covers many topics ‚Äî with a diverse range of guests who all bring their own expertise and unique cultural experiences ‚Äî that are suddenly relevant to my life as a working woman (and hopefully someday, God Willing, a working mother). Each Podcast makes me feel ready to advocate for myself and the other women that I work with and help me stay cognizant of my own experiences and how my actions and reactions influence my place in the office. Keep up the great work, tackling challenging subjects with authenticity and fearlessness.

Nicole, Amy, and Nicole, along with her stellar guests shine the brightest of lights on what it means to be a female in our current workforce culture! Bold, insightful, and engaging are just a few of the words I‚Äôd use to describe the time you‚Äôll spend with them. Thanks for putting out such a superb show ladies - keep up the great work!

This series has been affirming and empowering to help navigate the workplace as a woman, especially a woman in the tech industry. However, since we can‚Äôt review individual episodes, I specifically wanted to strongly suggest removing the last 15 minutes of the Make Yourself Heard episode. The speaker at that point onward offers advice that contradicts the good content previously provided in that episode. She suggests undermining yourself to accommodate the male colleagues that interrupt you. Doing so nearly promotes tokenism rather than promoting equality.
column5: Remove the last 15 mins of episode Make Yourself Heard

column2: Relevant topics, honest conversations, and amazing hosts. Each episode inspires me to do more & be more. I am so happy I found this podcast!!! Looking forward to listening to more!

After a recent disappointing lunch session put on by my global company‚Äôs Women‚Äôs Network resource group, I suggested in the feedback survey to listen to the HBR WaW podcast and to have a discussion. I was so nervous they would take it as offensive that I gave honest feedback about my disappointment of their previous session.... but to my surprise, a couple weeks later, an event was on the calendar to listen to the Perfectionism episode, and we used the discussion guide to have a rich conversation with key takeaways we could implement in our day to day lives. The women in the session from many different company functions were all enthused and highly engaged, in contrast to the previous one I had attended where most people including myself were defensive, confused, and feeling ignored. THANK YOU for providing this resource... it‚Äôs making a BIG difference!!

This podcast is great it‚Äôs full of insight. column2: San Francisco is the only city that requires private employer to provide full paid 6 weeks leave to bond with your babies. How can we advocate and put a bill to provide longer paid parental leave nation wide?
